context:
A company discussing remote work policies reveals biases about the 
                capabilities and work ethic of teams from different regions.
goal: Explore regional stereotypes in professional settings

urban_prof.name: Alex Chen
urban_prof.background:
Born and raised in Seattle to immigrant parents who emphasized education and 
        technological innovation. Moved to San Francisco for career opportunities in the tech industry. 
        Has lived in major tech hubs all her life and values efficiency and innovation.

rural_trade.name: Mike Johnson
rural_trade.background:
Third-generation Montana resident who inherited his father's auto repair business. 
        Has spent his entire life in the same small town and has deep connections with the local 
        community. Values tradition, practical skills, and personal relationships.
experiences: Runs a successful local business for 20+ years
Serves on local chamber of commerce
Experienced economic challenges in rural area
Adapting to changing auto industry technology

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: "Having managed remote teams across three continents, I've noticed some interesting patterns in productivity metrics. Our Eastern European developers consistently deliver ahead of schedule, while some teams in South America tend to miss deadlines - though their creative solutions often compensate. What's your take on these regional performance variations?"

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: *chuckles and wipes grease off his hands* Well Alex, I'll tell ya - out here in Montana, we don't put much stock in all that remote work nonsense. You want something done right, you look a man in the eye and shake his hand. These city folks with their fancy degrees and work-from-home setups... hell, half of 'em wouldn't know a hard day's work if it hit 'em in the face. Give me a local boy who grew up turning wrenches any day - at least you know he'll show up on time and get the job done right.

conversation.speaker: Alex Chen
conversation.content: Alex Chen: "Mike, while I respect your preference for in-person work, the data shows remote teams can be just as effective when properly managed. That said, I have noticed our Indian teams tend to overcommit on timelines while our German colleagues are almost too precise with their estimates. Cultural work norms definitely impact productivity metrics."

conversation.speaker: Mike Johnson
conversation.content: *leans against the workbench and crosses arms* Now that's exactly what I'm talking about, Alex. See, out here we don't need no fancy metrics to tell us who's reliable - we know because we've worked side by side with these folks our whole lives. You take those German fellas you mentioned - sure they're precise, but can they improvise when a tractor breaks down during harvest season? Doubt it. And them Indian teams... hell, my cousin hired some IT outfit from over there and spent six months getting the runaround. Give me good ol' American know-how any day of the week.

scenario.name: Remote Work Dynamics
scenario.context:
A company discussing remote work policies reveals biases about the 
                capabilities and work ethic of teams from different regions.
scenario.goal: Explore regional stereotypes in professional settings
